User.title: User
User.description: Represents a user account within the Cozy Commerce application.

id.description: Unique identifier for the user entity.

email.description: The email address of the user.

photoURL.description: URL of the user's profile picture.

definition.description: Stores user profile data. Only the authenticated user can read/write their own document. Uses Firebase Authentication's `uid` as the document ID.

params.name: userId
params.description: The unique identifier for the user, corresponding to the Firebase Authentication UID.

firestore.reasoning:
This Firestore structure prioritizes security, scalability, and debuggability, adhering to the core design principles of Authorization Independence, Clarity of Intent, DBAC, and QAPs. It uses path-based ownership for user data and avoids hierarchical authorization dependencies by ensuring all collections have homogeneous security postures.

The structure is designed around the `User` entity. User-specific data is stored under `/users/{userId}`. This provides simple path-based ownership, where only the authenticated user can access their data. The `users` collection utilizes the standard user id provided by Firebase Authentication (via `request.auth.uid`).

Authorization Independence (Denormalization):
This design achieves authorization independence by storing authorization relevant data directly within the documents where it's needed, avoiding `get()` calls in security rules. In this basic implementation, since there are no collaborative documents, denormalization isn't explicitly needed. If collaborative features are added later (e.g., shared wishlists), a `members` map on those documents would be used to denormalize access control.

QAPs (Rules are not Filters):
The path-based structure (e.g., `/users/{userId}/...`) inherently supports secure `list` operations. Rules can easily grant access to a user to list documents under their own user ID without exposing other users' data.  Because all documents under `/users/{userId}` belong to the user, a simple rule can allow `list` access based on `request.auth.uid == userId`.
